p.s: In his 65th Sonnet Since brass, nor stone, nor earth, nor boundless sea Shakespeare illustrates the importance of youthful beaty and the ability of love to transcend time.
Thus, he discusses that beauty alters and adressesaddresses a young man, named youth, with whom he has a deep and loving relationship.
The sonnet consists of 49s that are separated in three quatrains (from line one to four, give to eight, and nine to eleven) and a rhyming couplet.
Each quatrain provides two crross rhymes, the rhyme shemescheme is ABAB, CDCD, EFEF and GG.
In addition, the poet composed the poem in iambic pentameter, in order to represent the heartbeat, to stress the emotional atmosphere and the importance of love.
Furthermore he talks about certain themes.
Firstly, he discusses the aspect of mortality: every human being experiences death and goes through the process, where are youthful beauty alters throughout the time.

Speaking of time, it's certain to see that it also plays an essential role in the play wright's sonnet: Time passes, no impact of a human being can't change the fact that with the changes of time our youth does also change and become less significant.

Another important theme he mentions is the aspect of beauty: Shakespeare indicates that beauty does change and is influenced by the process of altering, whereas love does not: Love is not impacted by any circumstances; it is dominant and won't change, even though time passes and youth vanishes; the aspect of love remains essential and superior.
